attributes.comment:
Re: DHS Docket No. USCIS-2006-0044

I am opposed to the proposed U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services? (USCIS)
rule that would dramatically raise immigration application fees.

Under the current proposal, an application for permanent residency (green card)
would increase from $325 to $905 and a citizenship application would virtually
double from $330 to $595. Numerous other fees, including fingerprinting, will
increase as well.

These prices, coupled with the long waiting periods to obtain legal residency,
make it extremely difficult for immigrants to obey the law and work legally.
Just as an example, in 1988 we began the process to obtain a green card for a
woman whom we wanted to hire as a nanny for our children, the youngest of whom
was a newborn. Our daughter was 10 before the approval finally came through!

I believe that a better approach is the Citizenship Promotion Act recently
introduced by U.S. Representative Jan Schakowsky (D-IL), Senator Barack Obama
(D-IL) and Congressman Luis Gutierrez (D-IL). This Act would prohibit the USCIS
from raising immigration service fees until the USCIS has studied and reported
the need for the increases to Congress; it authorizes Congress to appropriate
funds to the USCIS for the immigration application process so that immigrants
are not forced to bear the entire cost of their application, and will also
expedite the application process by supporting efforts to educate immigrants
about the legal citizenship process, making electronic filing voluntary and
requesting a Government Accountability Office investigation into delays into the
background check process.

In light of this pending legislation and the hardship your new fee structure
would place on those trying to do the right thing, I urge you NOT to pass the
rule raising the fees.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Linda Black
